answers.author: Dan Weinheimer
answers.text:
You are in the best position to succeed in securing a grant if you have a project that you need funded rather than just looking to increase your number of grants secured. In other words, research the grant opportunities that exist currently (annual, specialized, fed/state, other) and plan far ahead. The best apps are the ones that are compelling based on need and fit. 
At a city-level, we have adopted a team approach where all departments are represented but coordinated through one office. There are regular meetings to exchange info and ideas and update where applications are relative to opportunities. The instinct to "chase" is still there but our greatest success comes from having a project in mind that is already planned and matching it to an opportunity.

answers.author: Thomas Couch
answers.text:
Dan;s philosophy is correct unless you live in a metro city or HUD entitlement community where you need to do active grants research for CD projects. Colleges and Universities offer the best transferable mthods for local government in what they refer to as pre-award and post award grants management. Even in a small to medium size community a management analyst or assistant manager could research, apply for, and manage grants. If you wish to consult me on specifics, please contact me at tmcouch@bullochcounty.net and we'll establish a dialogue.

In addition, eCivis offers an educational module and Grants Management component allowing cross-departmental collaboration, ARRA OMB 1512 reporting, increased transparency, tracking key milestones, ability to generate tasks that are sent to the grants team members, and hundreds of reporting options.  Please feel free to contact me if you are interested.  Sbaldwin@ecivis.com  www.ecivis.com

author: Kyle DeBord
text: Does anyone have any best practices/advice/suggestions on a framework or structure for Grants Management and Grants Pursuit for a county gov't?   We are a midwestern county (pop. ~350,000) and are attempting to increase the number of grants we pursue but there are some concerns about our capacity to properly manage an increased number of grants. I would love to hear about the grant management and grant pursuit frameworks used by others (need not necessarily be county gov't)  Thanks!
title: Grants Management and Grants Pursuit
